Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Spatial Stochastic Rare Events by Asymptotics and Weighted Ensemble Sampling to Understand how Cells Make Space
Award.AbstractNarration:
The surface of a cell is crowded with many different biomolecules. These include receptors and other large protein molecules that enable the cell to sense its environment. For example, cells that function as part of the immune system can sense extra-cellular molecular signals of infection. The cell surface is also a highly dynamic environment, and the movement and interactions of surface molecules play a crucial role in the response to extra-cellular signals. Mathematical modeling enables researchers to study these complex, dynamic, molecular processes in more detail than is currently afforded by experiments. The investigators will develop new mathematical approaches and computer simulation methods tailored to the study of how molecular motion on crowded cell surfaces influences cellular processes. The developed tools will enable researchers to predict the sequence of molecular events that initiate cell-cell interface formation and signaling processes. By enabling computational testing of novel strategies for biomolecular/cellular engineering, these tools will open up new means of discovery in areas such as immunotherapeutics. The investigators will contribute to broadening science participation by training undergraduate researchers in mathematical biology and scientific computing, and will carry out pedagogical activities with middle school students from groups underrepresented in science.

The specific focus of this research will be on modeling stochastic rare events in molecular diffusion. In many circumstances where molecular crowding occurs, un-crowding may also be critical. For example, in T cells, many large surface molecules must evacuate from a local region of the cell surface to allow for the T cell to interact with its target. This collective evacuation is a rare event relative to the timescale of individual molecular diffusion. The goal of this project is to develop a framework to study stochastic evacuation, including in rare event limits, and apply this framework to the T cell surface. Specific aims of this project are to: (1) Develop a combined asymptotic and computational rare event framework to solve diffusional evacuation in simple scenarios. (2) Develop enhanced spatially-distributed rare event methods capable of simulating complex scenarios. (3) Use the developed tools to understand how T cell surface molecules overcome or exploit rare evacuation. The mathematical novelty of this project is: the extension of asymptotic methods to effectively high-dimensional problems; the extension of computational rare event sampling methods, not only handling space but harnessing it; and the creation of synergies between asymptotic and computational approaches in a novel combined framework.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Before we can explore the impact of crowding on cellular processes (e.g., cell cycle, protein synthesis, actin polymerization, and liquid-liquid phase separation) we need to quantitatively measure crowding in living cells. We investigated the role of molecular crowding in fungal cells in a collaboration with Amy Gladfelter (UNC, Biology). The goal was to expand our understanding of cytoplasmic crowding using experimental data of stochastic nanoparticle motion in the crowded environment within living cells. Using machine learning based image analysis methods (a recurrent-convolutional neural network) developed by PI Newby (Univ. of Alberta, Mathematical and Statistical Sciences) and coworkers (Newby et al., PNAS 2018), sample paths of particle motion were extracted from 3D microscopy videos collected by graduate student Grace McLaughlin (UNC, Biology). Grace McLaughlin and PI Newby developed computational tools to analyze the tracking data. The space-time series data was used to infer spatially resolved properties (namely, particle diffusivity) of the cytosol using Bayesian statistics (Expectation-Maximization). We examined diffusivity because it is an indicator of crowding. Lower diffusivity means that nanoparticles are less mobile, which indicates increased crowding. We observed substantial heterogeneity in the cytoplasm within and between cells. Additionally, we measured a moderate cell cycle dependent drop in the diffusivity surrounding nuclei and a substantial drop near hyphal tips. This work resulted in a publication (McLaughlin et al., Molecular Biology of the Cell 2020).

An important byproduct of molecular crowding is liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS). However, the mechanistic relationship between crowding and LLPS is poorly understood. In a collaboration with postdoc Kelsey Gasior (UNC, Biology), Greg Forest (UNC, Mathematics), and Amy Gladfelter, we developed mathematical models of LLPS for our model system (Ashbya). Kelsey mentored Grace McGlaughlin, who developed codes to analyze simulation results of the LLPS model. This project resulted in two publications (Gasior et al., Physical Review E 2019; and Gasior et al., Bulletin of Mathematical Biology 2020).

The LLPS team formed a new collaboration in the final year with postdoc Haiyang Yu (UCSD, Ludwig Center for Cancer Research) and Don Cleveland (UCSD, Cellular and Molecular Medicine). We used LLPS modeling work (see above) to explain the anisotropic patterning of phase separated droplets in the nucleus. These droplets contained TDP-43, a major player in neurodegenerative disease. With our model, we were able to predict the presence of an unknown molecular species with a specific molecular interaction profile that colocalized to the droplet cores, while TDP-43 localized to an outer annular region near the droplet surface. This research resulted in a publication (Yu et al., Science 2021).
